item.title: Can we expect Xcode on the iPad this year?
item.description: It’s not a secret that I have been strong on the iPad becoming a real developer device in the near future. Yet, one thing is still missing in the grand scheme of things, and that is, first-party developer tooling.
item.content:
I decided to stir the waters a bit and ask the reader community:

A fully-featured Xcode running on the iPad for the upcoming iOS release. What are the odds? #WWDC20 #WWDC2020

— Preslav Rachev (@preslavrachev) June 10, 2020

What do you think? how likely is it? Answer the poll, or drop me a line below.

It’s not a secret that I have been strong on the iPad becoming a real developer device in the near future. Certain things have been possible for years, and I already wrote a lengthy post performing data-science-like tasks on an iPad, back in 2018:

Data Science on Your iPad
This article is a follow-up transcription to a talk I recently gave at a local Munich machine learning meetup. Unlike my previous talk, this time I wanted to convey the idea of using an iPad for actively running data science experiments, as opposed to passively consuming information. I illustrated my point with a few example iOS applications I personally use on a daily basis, which I hope would be good starting points to get the audience interested in the idea.
https://preslav.me |
Created with Linqable

Yet, one thing is still missing in the grand scheme of things, and that is, first-party developer tooling. Yes, as much as I dread it, I am speaking about Xcode coming to iPadOS. There have been rumours about this going on for years, but the feeling is really strong that it will be announced on this year’s WWDC in a few days:
